raw_text:
Tories urge 'change at the top'
 
 Tory delegates are gathering for what is expected to be their last conference before the general election, declaring Britain needs "a change at the top".
 
 The party goes into its spring forum trying to highlight what it sees as a clear choice between it and Labour. Tory co-chairman Liam Fox has opened proceedings with a speech criticising Tony Blair's record in government. Labour's rule has been characterised by "lost trust and failure to deliver", he told the Brighton conference. He also attacked the government's "failure" to control immigration and asylum and criticised its record on the NHS, telling delegates Labour cannot be trusted on education or crime. A Tory government would sort out the "shambles" of immigration, put patients before statistics and bring discipline to schools, he said. Dr Fox also underlined Tory promises to cut tax by £4bn.
 
 BBC political correspondent Shaun Ley says opinion polls suggest the Tories still lag some way behind Labour on the issues of health, education and the economy. Conservative leader Michael Howard, who had been due to welcome delegates to the conference on Friday, will address them in a lunchtime speech. His welcome address had to be postponed after he stayed in London to lead the party's opposition to the Prevention of Terrorism Bill in its lengthy progress through Parliament. The bill was finally passed on Friday evening, after more than 30 hours of debate. Mr Howard is likely to defend his party's handling of the bill, which was only passed after the Conservatives accepted Prime Minister Tony Blair's promise that MPs would be able to review it within a year.
llama3.2:1b: Tories urge "change at the top" with Liam Fox criticizing Labour's record and promising to sort out immigration, education, and discipline in schools. Tory leader Michael Howard will defend his party's handling of the Prevention of Terrorism Bill.
llama3.2:3b: Tory delegates gather for their last conference before the general election, urging "a change at the top". Liam Fox criticizes Labour's record, saying they have lost trust and failed to deliver on issues like immigration, asylum, NHS, education, crime, and tax cuts. Conservative leader Michael Howard addresses the conference after postponing his welcome speech due to Parliament debates on the Prevention of Terrorism Bill.
gemma2:2b: Conservative delegates at their spring conference are pushing for a change in leadership and emphasizing their contrast with Labour. Liam Fox highlights perceived shortcomings of Labour's government, including immigration issues, NHS performance, and education policies. He also promises tax cuts and emphasizes the party's plans to address these areas. Conservative leader Michael Howard is expected to address delegates later, after postponing his welcome speech due to the Prevention of Terrorism Bill debate.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key points:
- UK Conservative Party convenes for last meeting before election.
- Coalition parties urge change at top level.
- Prime Minister David Cameron expected to welcome delegates.
- Tory party focuses on immigration, education and health, criticizing Labour government's record in these areas.
- Tories still lag behind Labour on health, education and economy issues.
- Conservative leader Michael Howard is expected to address meeting attendees.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tories urge change at top during conference ahead of general election, criticizing Labour on health, education, and economy while promising tax cuts. Tories accuse Labour of failure in government due to lack of trust and inability to deliver on key issues like immigration control, NHS performance, education, crime, etc. Fox criticizes Blair's record, promising to reform immigration policy, increase patient care focus, discipline schools, and cut taxes by £4bn. Michael Howard will address delegates later amid controversy surrounding his opposition to the Prevention of Terrorism Bill passed after extended debate.
qwen2.5:3b: Tory delegates are meeting for their last conference before the general election, emphasizing a need for "change at the top." Tory co-chairman Liam Fox criticized Labour’s record under Tony Blair, highlighting issues like immigration control and NHS performance. He claimed that if the Conservatives were in power, they would address these problems by cutting taxes and improving education and healthcare. Conservative leader Michael Howard will give a speech addressing delegates, who are waiting for his arrival after he stayed in London to oppose the Prevention of Terrorism Bill, which was just passed following concessions made by the Tories.
opencoder:1.5b: Tory urges 'change at the top' during the conference. The party prepares for expected outcome by highlighting its clear choice between it and Labour. The party's co-chairman Liam Fox brings a speech criticizing Tony Blair's record on government. Labour has criticized "lost trust" and "failure to deliver", and he also attacked government's failure to control immigration, statistics and the NHS. A Tory government will tackle the 'shambles' of immigration, bringing discipline to schools. Dr Fox underlines potential cuts in tax.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details from the original text:

1. The Tories are urging "a change at the top" due to their perceived failure in government.
2. Labour has been criticized for its record on immigration, education and crime.
3. A Tory government would sort out the "shambles" of these issues by controlling them more effectively.
4. The party promises to cut tax by £4bn if elected.
5. The BBC political correspondent says opinion polls suggest the Tories still lag behind Labour on these issues.
6. Conservative leader Michael Howard is expected to address delegates in a lunchtime speech.
7. His welcome address had to be postponed after he stayed in London to lead the party's opposition to the Prevention of Terrorism Bill in its lengthy progress through Parliament.
8. Mr Howard is likely to defend his party's handling of the bill, which was only passed after the Conservatives accepted Prime Minister Tony Blair's promise that MPs would be able to review it within a year.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I have this query where the user wants me to summarize a given text into a concise summary. They specified that I should output only the summary in plain text without any explanations, formatting, or reasoning. 

First, I need to read through the provided text carefully. Let's break it down. The first sentence is pretty straightforward: "Tories urge 'change at the top'." That sets the tone for a political discussion about leadership.

Next, there's a section about Tory delegates attending their last conference before the election. They're trying to make a clear choice between themselves and Labour. There are details on who they are talking to—Liam Fox, a Tory co-chairman, is addressing a speech criticising Tony Blair, who was the previous leader.

Then, there's another part about Labour's leadership issues. They claim to have lost trust in the government, which includes things like immigration and healthcare. Labour's leader, Michael Howard, is set to give his address at the conference later, but he has to stay in London to oppose the recent terrorist bill proposal. This bill was controversial and took a long time to pass.

At the same time, a BBC political correspondent named Shaun Ley is using opinion polls to suggest that the Tories are still behind Labour on health, education, and economic issues. Mr. Howard's speech could be about defending his party's handling of the terrorist bill.

So, putting this all together, I need to condense these points into a summary without adding any extra details. The key ideas include the delegates' conference, their choice between parties, Labour's leadership shortcomings in areas like immigration and healthcare, Mr. Howard's upcoming speech, and the poll findings suggesting Tories are behind Labour.

I should make sure to keep it concise, only capturing the essential information from each section without going into too much detail. That way, the user gets a clear overview of what's happening in the political discussion around these topics.
</think>

The Tory delegates gather for their last conference before the general election, discussing the need for "change at the top." They highlight a choice between themselves and Labour. Speaker Liam Fox criticizes Tony Blair, while Labour claims lost trust and failure to deliver in areas like immigration and healthcare. Mr. Howard will address the conference, facing an unexpected delay due to opposition to the terrorist bill, which was passed after extensive debate. Shaun Ley's poll suggests the Tories lag behind Labour on health, education, and the economy.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Torie delegates are gathering for their spring conference, scheduled for later this week. The party has nominated Liam Fox as their co-chairman, who is delivering a speech criticizing the Labour government's record on key issues like immigration and education, along with the need to bring order back into the government's operations. Dr Fox emphasizes Torie promises to cut taxes by £4 billion and improve patient care, while also bringing discipline to schools and fixing the NHS. Despite falling short of polls, opinion remains split on the Tories' ability to deliver major shifts in policy. Conservative leader Michael Howard will be addressing delegates today after delaying his welcome speech due to his opposition to the Prevention of Terrorism Bill. The bill was finally passed this week, but Mr Howard is likely to defend the government's handling of it.
